channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: She's been falsely accused of starting the coronavirus. Her life has been turned upside down
item.description: Maatje Benassi, a US Army reservist and mother of two, has become the target of conspiracy theorists who falsely place her at the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, saying she brought the disease to China.

item.title: Trump is driving Birx to a tough spot. It's about to get even tougher
CNN's Jake Tapper asks Dr. Birx about Trump's disinfectant remark
item.description: Jake Tapper presses Dr. Deborah Birx on the President's claim that disinfectants can be used to treat coronavirus

item.title: WHO: 'Pandemic is far from over'
Bill Gates predicts when we'll get a coronavirus vaccine
item.description: Bill Gates, philanthropist and founder of Microsoft, discusses the timeline for a potential vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Germans face fines of up to $5,000 as wearing a face mask becomes mandatory
item.description: Public life changed considerably for most Germans on Monday as the wearing of masks became mandatory in many public spaces across the country.

item.title: The world's biggest car factory just reopened
Saudi Arabia stops death penalty for people who committed crimes as minors
item.description: Saudi Arabia is abolishing the death penalty for people who committed crimes as minors, the state-backed Human Rights Commission (HRC) said in a statement Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus could be tied to a rare but serious illness in children, UK doctors say
item.description: A small but rising number of children are becoming ill with a rare syndrome that could be linked to coronavirus, with reported cases showing symptoms of abdominal pain, gastrointestinal symptoms and cardiac inflammation, UK health care bosses and pediatrics specialists have warned.

item.title: CNN anchor: We have to report this, even though it's insane
item.description: CNN's Brian Stelter examines life during the coronavirus pandemic and how people in positions of power are handling it.

item.title: The virus hunters who search bat caves to predict the next pandemic
item.description: Before entering the cave, the small team of scientists pull on hazmat suits, face masks and thick gloves to cover every inch of their skin. Contact with bat droppings or urine could expose them to some of the world's deadliest unknown viruses.

item.title: New Zealand claims 'elimination' of coronavirus
item.description: New Zealand claimed Monday it had "eliminated" the coronavirus as the country announced the easing of restrictions from "level four" to "level three," with new cases in single figures.

item.title: Rumors surrounding Kim Jong Un not 'based on the facts' says former North Korean diplomat
Fauci's 'SNL' dream becomes Trump's nightmare
New satellite images show Kim Jong Un's compound
item.description: Newly released satellite images show Kim Jong Un's compound in Wonsan, North Korea, as questions circulate about the state of the North Korean leader's health. CNN's Will Ripley reports.

item.title: I bought a hotel and it was a huge mistake
item.description: Anyone currently whiling away the long hours of lockdown with when-this-is-all-over dreams of a fresh start in life, should heed this as a cautionary tale.

item.title: Parking lot turned into morgue as UK's ethnic communities suffer
item.description: A son grieves alone in an underground parking lot turned morgue, a daughter sheds tears for her father -- just two stories of heartbreak from communities disproportionately affected by Covid-19 in the UK. CNN's Phil Black reports.

item.title: US oil is plunging again on storage fears
People crowd Southern California beaches despite coronavirus concerns
Scaramucci: This seems to be Trump's pandemic strategy
item.description: Former White House Communications Director Anthony Scaramucci discusses how President Donald Trump and his administration are handling the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Supreme Court asks for additional briefings in Trump finances cases
item.description: The Supreme Court on Monday asked for additional briefings in two cases concerning President Donald Trump's bid to shield his financial documents from Congress.

item.title: Boris Johnson warns against relaxing UK lockdown
Watch glow-in-the-dark dolphins glide through the ocean
item.description: A photographer captured video of dolphins glowing as they glide through bioluminescent ocean water at night.

item.title: Neanderthal fathers were younger than Homo sapiens, but mothers were older, study says
item.description: When human ancestors left Africa and met Neanderthals in Europe 50,000 years ago, they had children together and clues were left behind in modern human DNA.

item.title: The Cold War spy plane that's still the world's fastest airplane
Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson hope their blood helps the coronavirus fight
item.description: Two of the world's most famous Covid-19 patients are willing to share their blood to help in the fight against the disease.

item.title: Six weeks trapped inside, these kids finally find some freedom
item.description: After being confined to their homes for more than a month because of Covid-19, Spain's youngest generation are allowed outside for limited periods. CNN's Scott McLean reports.

item.title: Contact tracing 101: How it works, who could get hired, and why it's so critical in fighting coronavirus
item.description: Thousands of Americans could soon join the ranks of disease detectives in one of the most important battles against coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus forced a group of teens to sail home across the Atlantic
item.description: As journeys home go, it was a particularly long and unusual one.

item.title: Common heartburn drug being studied as treatment for Covid-19
item.description: Hospitals in New York are giving Covid-19 patients heartburn medicine to see if it helps fight the virus, according to the doctor who initiated the trial.

item.title: Trump's outrageous suggestion comes with a dark history
item.description: Pandemics, even as they cause untold suffering, do more than create new problems. They reveal long-held cultural attitudes, approaches to faith in governance and differing beliefs about individual rights and trust in science. Historically speaking, these myriad responses reemerge from pandemic to pandemic in recycling patterns of seemingly historical truisms. We ignore, we deny, we blame.

item.title: Shop owner plans to reopen despite call from governor's office
item.description: Parts of Colorado are beginning to lift coronavirus restrictions. CNN's Gary Tuchman speaks with a local barber shop owner who plans to reopen, despite the fact that the state told him not to.

item.title: At West Point, is Trump speaking worth the risk?
item.description: As a graduate of West Point, I never thought I would write this, but the leadership at the US Naval Academy got it right. After telling the midshipmen to "stay at home" after spring break on April 10 and conducting distance learning classes since, Navy's Superintendent Vice Adm. Sean Buck canceled the Annapolis graduation and commissioning week to "safeguard the health and welfare of the entire Naval Academy family." Buck and Commandant of Midshipman Capt. T.R. Buchanan then approved a "virtual ceremony."

item.title: World no.3 tennis star rejects plans to help struggling players through global crisis
item.description: World no. 3 Dominic Thiem has rejected the notion that top tennis stars should provide financial support to the game's lower-ranked players due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Andy Cohen: As a gay man I was unable to donate plasma
item.description: CNN's Anderson Cooper speaks to TV host Andy Cohen about his experience trying to donate plasma in the wake of the pandemic and being turned away due to his sexuality.

item.title: NASA's 'worm' logo is back. But why did it disappear?
item.description: The worm is back. NASA's sleek and wavy logo from the 1970s is set to make its return on a SpaceX Falcon 9 scheduled to launch in May -- the first to carry astronauts to the International Space Station from American soil since 2011.

item.title: Why some kids are happier right now, and other unexpected effects of quarantine
item.description: Like most parents, Seagal Hagege, a mom of three in Irvine, California, wasn't exactly looking forward to sheltering in place.

item.title: Scientists create glow-in-the-dark plants
item.description: Fans of the "Avatar" movie will have long dreamed of lush jungles teeming with glowing plants.

item.title: Newcastle United takeover will 'greatly stain' Premier League, says Jamal Khashoggi's fiancée
item.description: The fiancée of late journalist Jamal Khashoggi has urged the English Premier League to block Newcastle United's potential takeover, given the involvement of Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF).

item.title: 'Parks and Recreation' co-creator growing beard for charity
item.description: "Parks and Recreation" co-creator Michael Schur is growing out his beard to imitate the character Mose, who he played on the television show "The Office," after promising his Twitter followers that he would to raise money for the Los Angeles Regional Food Bank.

item.title: Weird and wonderful food and drink pairings
item.description: Champagne with strawberries, red wine with steak, tequila with tacos and even Scotch with chocolate are familiar pairings of food and drink.

item.title: English soccer club 'appalled' after striker Moise Kean appears to breach lockdown to attend party
item.description: Everton Football Club says it is "appalled" after images emerged apparently showing striker Moise Kean at a party in violation of government coronavirus guidelines.

item.title: It's wrong to use two spaces between sentences, Microsoft Word says
item.description: Microsoft has made its typographical decree: Two spaces between sentences is too many.

item.title: Meryl Streep, Christine Baranski and Audra McDonald celebrate Sondheim in their bathrobes
item.description: Meryl Streep, Audra McDonald and Christine Baranski, boozing in their bathrobes while singing "The Ladies Who Lunch." This was the quarantine moment the world didn't know it needed -- until now.

item.title: 'American Idol' shot at 40 different locations using iPhones
item.description: The show must go on despite the pandemic and Sunday's "American Idol" returned with a new format.

item.title: Sportswashing: What is it and who practice it?
item.description: Sportswashing is a term used to describe corrupt or authoritarian regimes who use sport and sports events to whitewash their image internationally. Saudi Arabia is the latest to be accused of using this practice with the potential purchase of Newcastle United.

item.title: Director-General said the organization is 'concerned about the increasing trends in Africa, Eastern Europe, Latin America and some Asian countries'
item.description: Get info: Why you don't need to wipe down your groceries

item.title: Covid-19 has killed at least 206,000 worldwide
More than 55,000 have died in the US
North Korean media publishes letter from Kim Jong Un to South Africa's President dated April 27
item.description: • Rumors surrounding Kim not 'based on the facts' says ex-North Korean diplomat
